item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Homeowner’s ‘Cannons’ Warn Demolition Teams: No Closer
item.description: Determined to protect his home from being razed, a man in Henan Province has stationed six “cannons” outside it. They apparently cannot be fired, but they are drawing attention.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Deal to Move Okinawa Base Wins Approval
item.description: A long-simmering dispute between the United States and Japan over the fate of a Marine base on Okinawa seemed to have been resolved on Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and THOM SHANKER

item.title: Russian Inquiry Finds No Radiation Link to Arafat’s Death
item.description: Teams of scientists from France, Switzerland and Russia had been asked to determine whether polonium played a role in the 2004 death of Yasir Arafat, the former Palestinian leader.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Broadens New Crackdown on Brotherhood
item.description: With dozens of arrests and the seizure of land, stocks and vehicles, Egypt’s new rulers signaled that they had opened a wide-ranging war on every facet of the Muslim Brotherhood’s activities.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Egypt’s government accuses the Muslim Brotherhood of orchestrating a fatal attack on Tuesday.

item.title: Frederick Fox, Milliner to Royals, Dies at 82
item.description: Beginning in 1970, Mr. Fox designed more than 350 hats for Queen Elizabeth. His trademark skill, admirers said, was to mix whimsy and propriety.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Frederick Fox, shown in 1993, with a hat made for Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: Johannesburg Journal: South Africans Band Together, Finding a New Enemy in Highway Tolls
item.description: A new road toll system has prompted a battle of words between protesters and the South African government.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON
item.media:description: Protesters rallied this month against a toll system built by the South African government.

item.title: News Analysis: With Shrine Visit, Leader Asserts Japan’s Track From Pacifism
item.description: A visit to the Yasukuni Shrine highlighted Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s willingness to take on big political risks as he tries to build a more powerful Japan.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit to the Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo angered China and South Korea. Relations with both nations are already strained.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Soldiers Retake Town Seized by Rebel Group
item.description: Soldiers in the Democratic Republic of Congo have taken back a town in eastern Congo occupied by a Ugandan rebel group, a government spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Third Suspect Detained in Beating of Activist
item.description: Ukrainian authorities on Thursday increased the severity of potential charges in the case after initially deeming it a matter of “hooliganism.”
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Carnivorous Fish Attack Bathers in a River
item.description: An attack by a school of carnivorous fish injured 70 people bathing in an Argentine river, including seven children, who lost parts of their fingers or toes, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Antarctica: Ice Traps Ship Carrying a Scientific Expedition Team
item.description: Three icebreakers are on their way to an area off the coast of Antarctica to help free a vessel carrying 74 people that is stranded in thick sheets of ice, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,285 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Israeli Jets Strike Gaza Strip in Response to Rocket Attacks
item.description: The actions, the second in three days, continue a new wave of violence that has complicated peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As European Barriers Fall, Bulgarians Feel West’s Tug
item.description: With nine European Union countries about to lift labor restrictions, and with discontent at home, some in Bulgaria are finding it hard to stay.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Boryana Katsarova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petar Kyosev, 24, a law student, said, “I’m trying to do my best to stay here, but my country is not doing its best to make me stay.”

item.title: African Leaders Press for Peace in South Sudan
item.description: The president of Kenya and the prime minister of Ethiopia arrived in South Sudan for talks with President Salva Kiir on finding a solution to the fighting that has engulfed the young nation.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: South Sudanese soldiers on Wednesday in Bor, which the army retook after it fell to rebels. Violence continues to grip the country.

item.title: No Aid Seen in Syrian Town Despite a Deal to Lift Barriers
item.description: Government officials and rebels blame one another as no aid is yet delivered to the civilians in Moadhamiya, just outside the city limits of Damascus.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Big Spanish Labor Union Facing an Investigation on Misuse of Funding
item.description: The regional government of Andalusia contends $2.46 million in public money was spent illegally to pay for events and gifts to officials.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: A rally last month against budget cuts in Spain.

item.title: Prosecutor Overseeing Turkish Graft Inquiry Is Removed From Case
item.description: The removal of the prosecutor, Muammer Akkas, is a new sign of a profound power struggle over Turkey’s judiciary and police forces.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Volkan Furuncu/Anadolu Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A departing Turkish minister, Erdogan Bayraktar, waved Thursday as he left his post. He has called on Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan to resign.

item.title: Victory, and Setback, for Indian Opposition Leader
item.description: A court declined to prosecute Narendra Modi over his role in an ethnic riot in 2002, but the government ordered a formal inquiry into allegations against his top lieutenant.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party held posters of its leader, Narendra Modi, on Thursday after a court rejected a petition seeking his prosecution.

item.title: Thai Election Body Urges Vote Delay as Unrest Flares
item.description: After violent clashes in Bangkok, the Election Commission of Thailand called for the postponement of a vote scheduled for Feb. 2, adding to the political uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A police officer lay injured from a gunshot after a clash with protesters.

item.title: In Blue-Collar Toledo, Ohio, a Windfall of Chinese Investments
item.description: Toledo is hardly the only United States city pursuing investors from China, but the Chinese have noticed its location, housing stock and space.
item.dc:creator: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the past seven years, the ties between Toledo, Ohio, shown here, and China have grown numerous.

item.title: India Ink: Bad Scripts and Politics Make for a Bad Year in Tollywood
item.description: The Telugu-language film industry is facing its worst financial slump in a decade.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: N.T. Rama Rao, a Telugu language film star and former chief minister of Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: Letter from Washington: Appointing Political Friends to Be Ambassadors
item.description: In few democracies could someone go from political fund-raiser and media honcho to ambassador to assistant secretary of state, as Charles Rivkin might.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Dozens of Bodies Recovered After Violence in Central African Republic
item.description: Red Cross workers have recovered 44 bodies from the streets of Central African Republic's capital, Bangui, they said on Thursday after inter-religious fighting in the last two days.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: French soldiers on a patrol on Thursday in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic, where sectarian tensions continue to provoke violence.

item.title: U.S. Captive of Al Qaeda Makes a Plea to Obama
item.description: In a video message, Warren Weinstein, who was abducted in 2011, said that the United States had abandoned and forgotten him.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
